musicalLanguage.description: Tito Puente's Latin groove, made famous by Santana, is built on just two chords: Am7 and D7. This simplicity makes it perfect for beginners while the infectious Latin rhythm keeps it exciting. The left hand drives a montuno-style pattern while the right hand plays the catchy organ riff that everyone knows.
musicalLanguage.structure: Two-chord vamp throughout: Am7-D7 (8 bars with building intensity)
keyMoments: Bar 1: The Am7 riff — instant recognition. This is the hook.
Bar 2: D7 — the only chord change. Simple but the groove is everything.
Bars 5-8: The riff opens up with more rhythmic energy and fills.
teachingGoals: Two-chord vamp — mastering a groove with minimal harmony
Latin rhythm feel — the montuno pattern
Building intensity through rhythm and dynamics, not chord changes
styleTips: It's all about the groove — lock in the rhythm before worrying about notes
Left hand should be percussive and rhythmic
Think organ, not piano — keep the touch light and bouncy
